summary: A letter from the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists (ICIJ) to a Barclays Bank executive, posing detailed questions about Barclays' handling of suspicious transactions and compliance failures related to high-risk clients, including figures linked to the Epstein case, Russian oligarchs, and other alleged criminals. The document is part of a broader investigation into bank compliance and anti-money laundering systems.

persons.name: Fergus Shiel
persons.role: Project Manager and Editor at ICIJ
persons.context: Author of the letter, representing ICIJ in an investigation into bank compliance and anti-money laundering systems.

persons.name: Ivor Ichikowitz
persons.context: Subject of Barclays' suspicious activity reports and an Enhanced Due Diligence report over corruption allegations; his companies moved hundreds of millions through Barclays.

persons.name: Christopher Steele
persons.context: His firm, Orbis Business Intelligence, produced an Enhanced Due Diligence report on Ivor Ichikowitz for Barclays.

persons.name: Joyce Banda
persons.context: Mentioned in relation to payments from Ichikowitz's foundation to Bell Pottinger for image burnishing.

persons.name: Bradley Birkenfeld
persons.context: Recalled traveling for Barclays to attract wealthy clients to Switzerland for tax avoidance.

persons.name: Rinat Akhmetov
persons.context: Identified in a Ukrainian dossier as a leader of an organized crime group; his companies moved billions through Barclays despite bank concerns.

persons.name: Mark Omelnitski
persons.context: Named in connection with Ayrton Development Ltd. and the Rotenbergs' shell companies.

persons.name: Arkady Rotenberg
persons.context: Sanctioned Russian oligarch whose companies moved millions through Barclays; suspected owner of Ayrton Development Ltd.

persons.name: Andrey Dubrovskiy
persons.role: Alleged owner of Ayrton Development Ltd.
persons.context: Cited by Barclays UK Wealth as the real owner of Ayrton Development Ltd., contradicting New York's belief it was owned by Arkady Rotenberg.

persons.name: Boris Rotenberg
persons.context: Sanctioned Russian oligarch, brother of Arkady Rotenberg, whose companies transacted through Barclays.

persons.name: Igor Rotenberg
persons.context: Son of Arkady Rotenberg, also sanctioned; his companies were involved in transactions through Barclays.

persons.name: Dmitry Protsenko
persons.context: Represented companies in the Panama Papers that Barclays attributed to the Rotenbergs.

persons.name: Antony Jenkins
persons.context: Former CEO who was allegedly not fully briefed on a critical internal report about Barclays Wealth.

persons.name: Denis O'Connor
persons.context: Shareholder who questioned Barclays' culture and recalled a compliance employee's cynical remark.

persons.name: James Staley
persons.context: Barclays CEO rebuked for trying to unmask whistleblowers and under investigation for ties to Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Late sex offender; UK authorities are investigating Barclays CEO James Staley's ties to him.

persons.name: Munir Kaloti
persons.role: Founder and chairman of Kaloti Jewellery International
persons.context: Subject of a Barclays SAR; his company's accounts were under review for suspicious activity.

persons.name: Mukhtar Ablyazov
persons.role: Former chairman of Kazakh bank BTA
persons.context: Accused of embezzlement; Barclays facilitated transactions for him to registration agents like Mossack Fonseca.

persons.name: Dmytro Firtash
persons.context: Indicted on U.S. bribery charges; Barclays facilitated millions in transactions for his companies despite alleged organized crime ties.

persons.name: Janmohamed Mohamedali Rahemtulla
persons.role: Tanzanian resident, Senior Custodian of imamat assets
persons.context: Received over $175 million in his Barclays Switzerland accounts, raising compliance questions about potential terrorism financing.

persons.name: Lamine Diack
persons.role: Former head of international track and field federation
persons.context: Subject of prosecution in an Olympics bribery scheme; funds linked to the scheme moved through Barclays accounts.

persons.name: Ashish Chordia
persons.context: Owner of companies involved in transactions flagged for heightened money laundering risk by Barclays.

connections.description: Steele's firm Orbis Business Intelligence produced an Enhanced Due Diligence report on Ichikowitz for Barclays, detailing corruption allegations.
Ichikowitz's family foundation allegedly paid Bell Pottinger to help burnish Joyce Banda's image, per media reports cited by ICIJ.
Barclays facilitated billions in transactions for Akhmetov's companies despite internal concerns about his alleged ties to organized crime and money laundering.
Omelnitski's firm Markom Group set up shell companies for the Rotenbergs, as revealed in the Panama Papers and investigated by Barclays.
UK authorities are investigating Staley's ties to the late sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, as mentioned in the document.
Brothers and son (Igor) involved in sanctioned entities that conducted transactions through Barclays.

events.title: ICIJ Deadline for Barclays Response
events.description: ICIJ sets a deadline of 6 p.m. GMT for Barclays to respond to their questions regarding suspicious transactions and compliance issues.

events.title: Barclays Receives Orbis Report on Ichikowitz
events.description: Barclays UK Wealth receives an Enhanced Due Diligence report from Christopher Steele's firm Orbis, raising corruption concerns about Ivor Ichikowitz.

events.title: US Sanctions on Rotenbergs
events.description: The U.S. Office of Foreign Assets Control sanctions Russian billionaires Arkady, Boris, and Igor Rotenberg after Russia's invasion of Crimea.

events.title: Panama Papers Release
events.description: Release of the Panama Papers revealing offshore companies linked to the Rotenbergs and others, prompting Barclays to launch an investigation.
Barclays closes 198 accounts under the Markom relationship linked to the Rotenbergs, following its internal probe.
events.title: Barclays Closes Markom Accounts
FinCEN Section 311 Proposal on FBME
events.description: FinCEN proposes a Section 311 special measure against FBME bank, yet Barclays continued processing transactions for FBME customers afterward.

keyFacts: Barclays filed 104 suspicious activity reports identifying over $21 billion in suspicious activity, ranking fifth among banks reviewed by ICIJ.
Barclays facilitated $12.5 billion in money transfers involving nine billionaires on the Forbes list between 2009 and 2017, per ICIJ analysis of SARs.
Despite an internal report flagging corruption concerns, Barclays continued moving over $256 million for Ivor Ichikowitz and his companies from 2011 to 2017.
Barclays CEO James Staley is under investigation by UK authorities for his ties to the late sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.
Barclays processed over $61 million in transactions for sanctioned Russian oligarchs Arkady, Boris, and Igor Rotenberg between 2012 and 2016.
